description: From Medieval Latin prognosticus, from Ancient Greek προγνωστικός (prognōstikós, “foreknowing”), from πρό (pró) + γνωστικός (gnōstikós, “of or for knowing, good at knowing”), from γιγνώσκω (gignṓskō, “to learn to know, to perceive, to mark, to learn”).

adjectives.description: prognostic (comparative more prognostic, superlative most prognostic)

entries.meaning: Of, pertaining to or characterized by prognosis or prediction.

examples: There are several opinions as to what he meant  But no one considers it a happy prognostic.

entries.meaning: A sign by which a future event may be known or foretold.
examples: Careful observers may foretell the hour  (By sure prognostics) when to dread a show’r.  While rain depends, the pensive cat gives o’er  Her frolics, and pursues her tail no more.
